ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None. Everything was done via an online live lecture.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Most of this course was doing my thesis research, but we had to attend Monday lectures with the first-year grad students on scientific/research ethics. Didn't learn much, as most of it was common sense.
In-person experience in an academic lab + accompanying material in research ethics

In lecture, I learned about ethics in scientific research, definitions and motivations of plagiarism, fabrication, and falsification of data. You also do research in lab, but this varies depending on which lab you are in.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: getting to do research! Weaknesses: pretty much everything about the required Monday lecture  for example, whenever we talked about issues such as plagiarism/scientific misconduct/etc., the examples were of women or POCs (or women POCs).

Strengths include an overview of scientific ethics and group discussion on motivations for breaking ethics. Weaknesses include lectures going over, and quite varied workloads among students in different labs. Keeping up with lab work is challenging, so you need to make sure you have a steady schedule for that.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Wasn't incredibly engaging, would probably have been made better if a recording was available.
Breakout rooms were great to discuss papers we read and such.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You only have to take this course/receive permission to take this course if you're a senior chemistry major and it's required... Most of my evaluation is colored by the required Monday lecture rather than my actual research lab (which is great).
Must take for a Chemistry major

If you are taking this course, you are most likely doing it for the senior requirement. I would not recommend this course to any one else, since you can easily just do lab work outside of this course.
